div.head: Dying to Divulge: The determinants of, and relationship between, desired and actual disclosure
div.p: The desire to disclose thoughts and information with others is fundamental to the human experience, and has been facilitated by the rapidly increasing number of applications and social media outlets that enable, and indeed promote, interpersonal disclosure. As these channels are often public, or veiled in privacy claims that belie vulnerability, the desire and decision to share information with others is worthy of investigation. Recent studies (e.g., Tamir & Mitchell, 2012) suggest that information-sharing may be inherently pleasurable, particularly when the information relates to one's own thoughts and feelings. An extensive literature further documents health, psychological, and social benefits resulting from interpersonal disclosure (e.g., Collins & Miller, 1994;Lambert et al., 2013;Langston, 1994;Pennebaker, 1997;Reis et al., 2010). At the same time, self-disclosure exposes individuals to scrutiny, the possibility of criticism, and the negative consequences that accompany rejection and reputational damage (Jourard, 1971;Kelly & McKillip, 1996). This is particularly true in the Internet age, in which interpersonal communications are often both public and permanent character. A substantial body of literature has emerged to address the high stakes of disclosure from a privacy perspective -that is, to identify those factors that heighten privacy concerns and discourage disclosure (for an overview, see Acquisti, Brandimarte & Loewenstein, 2015). It is important to complement such a research program with the investigation of factors that encourage disclosure, and to enhance our understanding of how and why people make the consequential decision to disclose to others, holding privacy concerns constant.

The current paper investigates disclosure through a novel lens, focusing not only on the decision to disclose but on the psychological desire to disclose that may or may not result in actual disclosure. We argue that these are meaningfully separate constructs and that understanding when and why the two diverge is a worthwhile endeavor. This paper begins with a review of the literature related to disclosure, from research on general self-disclosure in interpersonal communications to research on disclosure in specific contexts (e.g., whistleblowing) or of specific content (e.g., gossip). We conclude from this review that insufficient attention has been paid to the psychological drivers that precede -and differentially engenderdisclosure. That is, the extant literature has explored what types of information people ultimately share and why they do so, limiting the scope of this body of research to that information which was ultimately disclosed and neglecting the information that was withheld. The latter is important, however, as an individual who withholds a piece of information in one context may succumb to the desire to disclose in different circumstances.

To address this gap in the literature, we present findings from two exploratory studies that examine the types of information people are most eager to share, the contextual factors and individual characteristics that moderate or intensify the desire to share, and the circumstances under which this desire is most likely to translate into actual sharing. The first study involves a

survey of predominately open-ended questions regarding situations in which participants were "dying" to share information, with the goal of identifying the information and contexts that elicit the intense, almost visceral, desire to disclose. The second study -also a survey, but one that includes a between-subject manipulation of valence -includes mainly closed-ended questions asking about specific types of experiences that respondents may have had, and whether they wanted to, and did, share the experience with others, and if so, with whom. The first study represents an unguided probe into the universe of possible experiences that individuals want to communicate to others, and, informed by the results of Study 1, the second study quantifies the desire to share and presents causal evidence for the role that valence and domain play in dictating both the desire and propensity to disclose.

In examining the types of information that people actually share, we replicate findings from prior research that the decision to disclose a thought, experience, or piece of information with a known other is a function of its emotionality and valence (as in Berger & Milkman, 2012;Gable, Reis, Impett, & Asher, 2004;Luminet, Bouts, Delie, Manstead, & Rimé, 2000;Rimé, 1989;Rimé, Mesquita, Boca, & Philippot, 1991). In both studies, we find that negative information or experiences are less likely to be communicated to others than positive information or experiences. Interestingly, however, Study 1 suggests that individuals do experience a comparably strong desire to share negative information, but are less likely to act on that desire.

We further find in Study 1 that the propensity to withhold is much more common when the negative information is about oneself than about others. We also find tentative evidence that valence interacts with novelty: as the rarity of a positive experience increases, so too does the number of people in whom participants confide, whereas the same pattern does not hold for negative experiences. The results from these studies allow us to rank different topics based on individuals' desire, and ultimate likelihood, to discuss them with others.

People share different types of information for different reasons, and an additional goal of this research is to identify some of the diverse motives that drive the desire and decision to disclose. We use a series of composite measures of various motives, adapted largely from Berger (2014), and of traits, many of them heretofore unexplored in the disclosure context, to model the underlying decision-making process leading to information sharing. The results confirm findings in the existing literature related to gender differences, but reveal that the robust tendency for women to disclose more often and more widely than men depends crucially on valence: male and female participants are equally eager and likely to share positive information, but female participants are more likely than their male counterparts to share negative information. In addition to gender differences, statistical analyses reveal that the desire to disclose and the ultimate decision to disclose are driven by different motives. Specifically, we find that the selfenhancement motive is predictive of one's desire to disclose information but not whether or not they act on that desire, and present bias is inversely related to the ultimate decision to disclose negative information.

Finally, we asked respondents to our survey to reflect on their own disclosure behavior, both in terms of what they believe motivates their desire to share and on the frequency with which they act on their desire. Results from the latter exercise provide further support for the value of distinguishing between the desire and decision to disclose. In Study 1, the vast majority (80%) of participants were able to recall a time when they were "dying" to tell someone something but ultimately withheld the information, and in Study 2 70 percent of respondents have experienced either a desire to disclose or to withhold information but ultimately failed to act on that desire. Along the same lines, Study 2 responses reveal that people often see themselves as "over-sharers" who share more -or "under-sharers," who share less -than they believe that they should, normatively speaking. Given that affective factors are often responsible for deviations between actual and self-perceived normative behavior, these results reinforce an idea that is prominent in many of the other findings in the paper, namely, that affective factors play an important role in sharing.

The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. The following section outlines the relevant literature, after which we briefly describe our research goals in the context of that literature. The first and second studies are presented in the two subsequent sections, and the final section concludes.

div.head: Prior Research on Information-sharing
div.p: Reflecting the integral role that self-expression and interpersonal communication play in our daily lives, substantial research has examined different facets of information-sharing behavior. We group this research into two broadly-defined categories: what people share, and why people share. The former category involves research on the types of information and experiences people ultimately disclose to others, both in terms of the nature and content of the information shared. The latter category explores the motives that drive people to disclose, as well as the contextual factors and individual differences that influence actual disclosure. We use these broad categories to structure an extensive review of the literature, after which we discuss an area that we believe is under-explored, namely, the desire to disclose, which we argue precedes, but is not perfectly predictive of, the act of disclosing. Given our interest in the psychological antecedents of disclosure, we restrict our review of the literature to those studies involving voluntary disclosure driven largely by the pursuit of psychological, as opposed to material, motives. A parallel literature in economics focuses on strategic motives for disclosure (e.g., Lundholm & Van Winkle, 2006;Masiliūnas, 2017).

A critical first step in reviewing the literature on disclosure is to identify what constitutes disclosure and identify the boundaries of this construct within the existing literature. A great deal of work in this space focuses on self-disclosure, defined as "making the self known to others" (Jourard & Lasakow, 1958, p. 91) through "any information exchange that refers to the self, including personal states, dispositions, events in the past, and plans for the future" (Derlega & Grzelak, 1979, p. 152). This definition requires that the exchange is made with the deliberate intention to divulge something personal about oneself to at least one other person (Greene, Derlega, & Mathews, 2006), but is silent on the factors that precipitate disclosure. Thus, disclosures can include spontaneous revelations made to selected confidantes in naturalistic settings as well as information shared in response to questions posed by another party (e.g., an experimenter or confederate, a fellow study participant). Our coverage in this review is, however, broader. The disclosures we discuss need not be private, nor even about oneself. This is in line with literature suggesting that the sharing of seemingly impersonal information, such as product reviews, can in fact communicate information about oneself (Berger & Heath, 2007;Chung & Darke, 2006;Lampel & Bhalla, 2007) and serve self-enhancement goals by establishing oneself as informed (Ritson & Eliott, 1999).

div.head: What People Share
div.p: We begin with a discussion of research that explores information disclosure across domains before providing examples of research programs that focus exclusively on disclosure within a single domain. Afterward, we discuss the characteristics of the information itself (e.g., emotionality, valence) that drive disclosure.

div.head: Domains
div.p: Some of the earliest literature on self-disclosure set out to identify those informational domains most likely to be discussed with others. For instance, the Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (SDQ; Jourard & Lasakow, 1958) required respondents to indicate the degree and accuracy with which they had communicated various aspects of themselves to others, captured by 60 items ranging from attitudes and opinions (e.g., thoughts on religion, parenting), tastes and interests (e.g., favorite foods, hobbies), information about work and finances, and perceptions of their personality, physical appearance, and well-being. The authors found that respondents were least likely to discuss aspects of themselves related to money, personality, and body/health. Although the validity of the SDQ has come into question in the intervening decades (e.g., Lubin & Harrison, 1964;Cozby, 1973), many studies have adopted a similar approach to assessing disclosure across domains. Balswick and Averett (1977) asked participants to report how often (i.e., never, seldom, often, or very often) they disclose feelings across 16 dimensions (e.g., resentment, grief, elation), while Argyle, Trimboli, and Forgas (1988) had respondents rate their likelihood of discussing each of 19 topics -such as personal problems or daily events ranging from the mundane (e.g., reading a book) to the more noteworthy (e.g., a fire or accident) -with a specific person from one of 12 possible relationship categories. More recently, Consedine, Sabag-Cohen, and Krivoshekova (2007) presented respondents with 33 topic areas (e.g., sexual activities, shameful events, relationships, beliefs) and 10 possible interpersonal targets (e.g., partner, female friend, male friend, coworker, neighbor) and had participants indicate the extent to which they had discussed each topic with each possible confidante, from 0 ("have not discussed this topic at all/would not discuss it were it relevant") to 4 ("have discussed this topic fully and completely/would do so if it were relevant"). These designs provide a model for Study 2 of the present paper, in which we present participants with 18 different scenarios spanning the domains of identity and beliefs, work and finances, health, relationships (i.e., family, friends, romantic), and trivial daily events. The key point of differentiation is that our main focus is not on the propensity to share but rather the desire to share. Studies such as those described above are useful for uncovering important interactions between domain, individual characteristics, and contextual factors. Alternatively, some researchers have focused on disclosures made within a single domain, with the aim of revealing some truths about the disclosure process or content that will help to improve outcomes in the domain of interest. Below we briefly introduce some of the larger literatures that adopt this approach. We do not discuss the results from these specific domains in great detail; rather, specific results that generalize to disclosure more broadly are integrated with the findings discussed throughout the remainder of the literature review, that is, from the Nature of Content section onward, as appropriate.

div.head: Consumer
div.p: Experience. An extensive literature stems from research in marketing and consumer behavior and investigates a specific type of disclosure, "Word of Mouth" (WOM), defined by Westbrook (1987) as "informal communications directed at other consumers about the ownership, usage, or characteristics of particular goods and services or their sellers" (p. 261).

Recent research suggests that such disclosures constitute a nontrivial portion of interpersonal, and particularly online, communication. For instance, in an analysis of over 150,000 Twitter posts, Jansen, Zhang, Sobel, and Chowdury (2009) found that approximately 19% of tweets included some mention of a brand or corporation. Researchers and marketers alike have sought to understand the factors that lead customers to discuss their consumption experiences, given that such communications are extremely influential: According to a recent Nielsen report, 92% of consumers trust recommendations from friends and family over all forms of advertising, and only 58% reportedly trust the messages found on company websites (Nielsen, 2012). The propensity to disclose consumption experiences was initially thought to depend on customer satisfaction, with WOM characterized by a slightly asymmetric U-shaped function of satisfaction: highest at the two extremes but slightly higher for dissatisfied than for satisfied customers (Anderson, 1998). De Matos and Rossi (2008) extended the list of WOM antecedents to include other brand-related experiences, such as quality, trust, and perceived value. More recently, however, researchers characterized WOM as reflecting the interplay between features of the message content (De Angelis, Bonezzi, Peluso, Rucker, & Costabile, 2012), goals of the discloser (Alexandrov, Lilly, & Babakus, 2013;Berger, 2014), and contextual factors (Berger & Iyengar, 2013;Berger & Schwartz, 2011;Eisingerich, Chun, Liu, Jia, & Bell, 2014). These studies address disclosure content, motives for disclosing, and context; as such, the specific findings from these studies are discussed below under the sections entitled Nature of Content, Motives for Disclosing, and Modality and Context, respectively.

div.head: Disclosure of Stigmatized Group Membership.
div.p: Juxtaposed against the relatively impersonal and largely risk-free nature of WOM disclosures 1 is the decision to reveal a stigmatized disposition or condition, that is, to "come out of the closet." The term "coming out" is most commonly applied to revealing one's sexual identity or orientation to those in his or her social network, but can be understood more broadly as "deciding to no longer hide one's discreditable stigmatized condition" (Corrigan et al., 2009, p. 366). In this way, the experience of disclosing information about one's sexuality can extend to revelations by individuals with mental health issues (Bos, Kanner, Muris, Janssen, & Mayer, 2009;Corrigan et al., 2009), chronic illness (Kaushansky, Cox, Dodson, McNeeley, Kumar, & Iverson, 2017), particularly HIV/AIDS (Armistead, Morse, Forehand, Morse, & Clark, 1999;Marcellin et al., 2017;Serovich, 2001), or to individuals who have experienced trauma such as abuse (Yoshioka, Gilbert, El-Bassel, & Baig-Amin, 2003) or pregnancy loss (Andalibi & Forte, 2018). One strand of this literature explores the considerations that precipitate the decision to disclose one's status to others, typically modeling this decision as a cost-benefit analysis wherein costs can include shame, damaged relationships and discrimination, and potential rewards include feelings of acceptance, community, and emotional support (Corrigan et al., 2009;Serovich, 2001). In another stand of the literature, members of the stigmatized group are interviewed about their experience coming out (or remaining closeted) with the goal of identifying predictors of ultimate disclosure, disclosure targets, and consequences. Targets can vary as a function of the discloser's age, ethnicity, perceived social support, the strength and intimacy of family ties, and, in the case of victims of domestic violence, severity of the abuse (Armistead et al., 1999;Waldner & Magrader, 1999;Yoshioka, Gilbert, El-Bassel, & Baig-Amin, 2003). Much like the results discussed in below under Outcomes and Consequences of Disclosure, the ultimate outcome of disclosure is typically positive, including deeper relationships with the disclosure target (Bozett, 1980), relief and healthy sense of self (Bozett, 1980;Mosher, 2001), and higher self-esteem and self-efficacy through the reduction of self-stigma (Corrigan et al., 2010). Interestingly, however, this can vary by gender: Pachankis, Cochran, and Mays (2015) find that women who remain closeted are at high risk for depression, whereas men are at increased risk of depression and anxiety just after coming out. It is worth noting that there exists a plethora of additional work in this area that explores the decision to disclose to healthcare professionals or in a counseling environment (e.g., Baumann & Hill, 2016;Kelly & Achter, 1995;Morrison & Downey, 2000;Matthews & Peterman, 1998). While it is possible that some patients do experience a powerful desire to share, we anticipate that such disclosures to health care providers are largely guided by pragmatics and are thus beyond the purview of the present research.
Gossip. Another active area of research related to disclosure involves the transmission of gossip, defined as the "exchange of information about absent third parties" (Foster, 2004, p. 81).

Despite its frequent condemnation, gossip comprises a substantial portion of disclosures, by some estimates accounting for approximately 60% of adult conversations (Emler, 1994). Some have maintained that gossip actually serves the interests of the group (Gluckman, 1963), albeit, in some cases, at the expense of the individual (Paine, 1967). According to this interpretation, gossip provides the information necessary for social comparison processes (Wert & Salovey, 2004) and serves to teach social norms in a narrative form (i.e., how the violation of norms led to others' misfortune; Baumeister, Zhang, & Vohs, 2004). Gossip can also constrain self-serving behavior that would otherwise harm the collective interest; for example, Beersma and Van Kleef (2011) found that experimental subjects contributed more resources to a group task when they were led to believe that their decisions were identifiable and group members were able to gossip.

It should not be surprising, then, that divulging gossip can have different consequences for the discloser depending on the message's alignment with social norms. For example, Wilson, Wilczynski, Wells, and Weiser (2000) found that participants exposed to vignettes wherein gossip was shared about a violation of a norm -for example, students cheating -judged the gossiper (target) more favorably (harshly) than vignettes in which a lesser norm is violated, for instance, students' sycophantic behavior. One's propensity to disclose gossip, then, is likely influenced by his or her awareness of these factors and perceptions about gossip generally. To assess individual differences in the tendency toward gossip, Nevo, Nevo, and Derech-Zehavi (1993) developed the Tendency to Gossip Questionnaire (TGQ), in which participants indicate how frequently they transmit gossip and how much they enjoy doing so. The authors find that this measure correlates negatively with the need for social approval and is positively related to various other dispositional characteristics, including interpersonal curiosity and interest in people-oriented professions, such as counselors or sales managers.
Whistle-Blowing. Somewhat related to the literature on gossip is that of whistle-blowing, which also involves the disclosure to others about third-party violations of social norms or laws.

Whereas a charitable interpretation of gossip is that it functions to punish past, or forestall future, transgressions, whistle-blowers act explicitly in pursuit of this goal, typically at great professional or personal peril, and a key distinction between whistle-blowing and mere gossip is the choice of disclosure target. Whistle-blowing is defined as "the disclosure by organization members (former or current) of illegal, immoral, or illegitimate practices under the control of their employers, to persons or organizations that may be able to effect action" [italics added] (Near & Miceli, 1985, p. 4). This definition includes both external and internal whistle-blowing.

The latter type involves "disclosure to sources within the organization (for example, members of upper management and supervisors) who can bring about effective change regarding a perceived wrongdoing," but excludes "peer reporting," that is, disclosure to coworkers (King, 1999, p. 316). Some of the literature on whistle-blowing explores the differential outcomes for the organization and the individual in cultures that support or suppress "speaking up" to varying degrees. Of particular relevance to the present literature review are those studies that explore the antecedents and correlates of the decision to speak out against corporate misconduct. These correlates can involve features of the organization, including organizational structure (King, 1999), ethical culture (Kaptein, 2011), and compensation structure (Rose, Brink, & Norman, 2018), as well as characteristics of the individual whistleblower. In terms of this final category, Miceli and Near (1988) model whistleblowing as a prosocial behavior more likely to occur among professional employees with a longer tenure, a more positive relationship with their work, and recent positive recognition for their performance. This is consistent with research that finds that the decision to disclose organizational misconduct is positively correlated with job satisfaction and self-efficacy (Yu, Sirsat, & Neal, 2019), as well as holding a leadership role such as union representative (Bjørkelo, Einarsen, Nielsen, & Matthiesen, 2011). Relatedly, in a test of willingness to use online reporting systems, Lowry, Moody, Galletta, and Vance (2013) presented full-time professionals with a series of hypothetical organizational failures that varied in terms of the risk it posed to the organization and the risk that reporting the failure presented to the employee (i.e., variation in anonymity). They find that the belief that a failure should be reported, and one's sense of responsibility to do so, increased with the risk of the failure to the organization and decreased with perceived personal risk to oneself, which is in turn a function of anonymity and trust. On the whole, research on the individual determinants of whistle-blowing have produced somewhat inconsistent results (Vadera, Aguilera, & Caza, 2009), particularly in terms of demographic characteristics (Mesmer-Magnus & Viswesvaran, 2005).

div.head: Nature of Content
div.p: In the above subsection we discussed the different domains that have received attention in the extant literature. In this subsection, we explore the question of what people share; that is, the qualities of an experience or piece of information that increase its likelihood of being communicated to others, independent of the topic or domain.

Emotionality. Perhaps the most consistently identified driver of disclosure is emotionality. A large body of research centers around the social sharing of emotion, which entails openly communicating to others the circumstances of, and one's reactions to, an emotioneliciting event (Rimé, 1989). In a series of six studies, Rimé, Mesquita, Boca, and Philippot (1991) find that 90% of study participants reportedly shared emotional experiences after they occurred, often on the same day as the occurrence, and that sharing was positively correlated with the disruptiveness of the event. The propensity to share emotional events has also been shown experimentally. For example, participants who viewed a more intense emotional film engaged in significantly more social sharing with a close friend in the waiting room, or with others in the days following the experiment, as compared to those who saw less emotionally evocative excerpts (Luminet, Bouts, Delie, Manstead, & Rimé, 2000). Participants in a study by Berger and Milkman (2012) reported being more likely to share content that evoked high-arousal emotions, such as anger or awe, than low-arousal emotions, such as sadness. The same study additionally found that the degree to which content arouses emotion is highly predictive of whether a newspaper article will "go viral." Indeed, even non-emotional arousal can impact sharing behavior: propensity to share a neutral article or video was elevated among study participants whose arousal was heightened by watching an amusing or anxiety-producing film clip, or merely by jogging in place (Berger, 2011). This is consistent with research by Heath, Bell, and Sternberg (2001), who find that the ideas that propagate in the social environment (i.e., "memes") are those that have survived a selection process that depends on their ability to evoke specific emotions consistently across individuals. The authors provide evidence supporting the counterintuitive result that stories are more likely to be shared with others if they evoke greater levels of disgust, as indicated by the self-reported likelihood of passing along various urban legends, as well as the frequency with which disgusting urban legends are featured on various web sites.

In Study 1 of the present paper, we explore the emotionality of the language used to describe experiences that elicited an intense desire to share and explore whether differences in this language emerge according to whether the experience was ultimately withheld or disclosed to others. In addition, in consideration of the above described research, we ensure that the domains covered in Study 2 cover a wide range of emotions that represent the full spectrum of experiences that an individual may wish to share with others.

Valence. Another factor found to influence whether an individual ultimately decides to share information is valence. In an early study on self-disclosure, Berman, Murphy-Berman, and Pachauri (1988) asked participants how free they would feel to discuss different topics with their best friend and varied both the valence of the information and who the information was about (i.e., oneself vs. a family member). They observed a significant preference for disclosing positive rather than negative information, and found that this effect was even more pronounced for information regarding one's family. This penchant for positive disclosures is robust across research areas. In the same study that found people to be more likely to share high-arousal content, Berger and Milkman (2012) observe an overall predilection for sharing positivelyvalenced content. This is consistent with a diary study by Gable, Reis, Impett, and Asher (2004) in which participants kept a record of the positive events that transpired each day. Participants reportedly "let others know about the event/issue" (i.e., selected some value above 0 on a 5-point scale from "not at all" to "very much") between 60% and 80% of the time, but this portion was lower for less positive experiences. Valence also plays an important indirect role in the decision to share information. Although people generally prefer to pass along less surprising (i.e., moderate) information, they are more likely to share unusual news when it is congruent with the emotional valence of the topic being discussed. For instance, students are more likely to share information about an exceptionally high death rate (negative information) among mugging victims in a nearby park (negative domain) than a surprisingly low acceptance rate (negative information) for graduate programs (positive domain), and vice versa (Heath, 1996).

Highly related to the present paper is work by De Angelis, Bonezzi, Peluso, Rucker, and Costabile (2012). The authors identify two distinct stages in the sharing of WOM information, generation and transmission. Generation involves conveying information about one's own personal experiences with products and services, whereas transmission is when consumers share information about the experiences of others. With this distinction, the authors can account for the dissemination of positive and negative WOM: both generation and transmission are driven by the self-enhancement motive, but participants with low self-esteem or a threatened self-view are found to generate more positive WOM -that is, share information about their own positive experiences -and transmit more negative WOM -that is, pass along negative information that they heard about the experiences of others. This effect is moderated by how attached the consumer is to the third-party whose experience they are transmitting. In Study 1 of the present paper, we explore whether this finding extends beyond the WOM context by coding both the valence and self-relevance of open-ended responses about any experience that respondents were reportedly "dying to share" with others.

Novelty. Perhaps not surprisingly, topics that are more interesting are often more likely to be discussed with others (Heath, Bell, & Sternberg, 2001). As a result, individuals may consider the novelty of information when deciding whether or not to share it. Participants in Cooney, Gilbert, and Wilson (2017) preferred to tell their conversational partners about a video that their partner had not seen (i.e., that was novel) over one that they both had viewed during the experiment. This preference was driven by the (incorrect) expectation that novel information will be more interesting to, and thus elicit greater enjoyment from, the listener. However, the positive relationship between sharing and novelty may be moderated by the topic's inherent controversy. Chen and Berger (2013) find that willingness to discuss a topic with others is first increasing and then decreasing in controversy, which they explain in terms of the dual impact of interest and discomfort. It should be noted, however, that both of these studies entail a slightly different paradigm from those reviewed thus far, in that the recipients of the information were strangersfellow experimental participants in Cooney, Gilbert, and Wilson (2017) and other internet users in Chen and Berger (2013). It is an empirical question whether these factors operate in a similar manner in the sharing of information with a self-selected audience, such as a friend or family member.

In Study 2 of the present research, we use a feature of our study design -namely, the opportunity for respondents to opt out of answering questions about experiences they have not had -to estimate the rarity of the different experiences that subjects have had, which we can then use as a proxy for the novelty of the information. We then explore whether novelty, measured in this fashion, interacts with valence in determining the desire and decision to disclose. Salience. A final, highly intuitive determinant of the likelihood that a particular piece of information will be disseminated is its psychological salience. Salience can increase due to recent or repeated exposure, as in Berger and Schwartz (2011), who explore the impact of environmental cues on the propensity to tell others about consumer product experience. They find that a key determinant of a product's "word-of-mouth" is its accessibility, that is, its public visibility and the frequency of related environmental cues. Other inherent qualities about the information or experience can also increase its memorability: memory is greater for things that are surprising or counterintuitive, as well as emotional (Dutton & Heath, 2011). We note this work here as it presents an important qualification to the findings from the open-ended questions in Study 1 presented below, which we take steps to overcome in the research design of Study 2.

div.head: Why People Share (or Withhold) Information
div.p: The question of what type of information people share is closely related to the question of what drives people to share, and often the former is informative about the latter. In what follows, we present research on the outcomes of information sharing, the motives that drive individuals to disclose or withhold information, and discuss how various features of the environment and individual differences can influence the propensity to disclose.

div.head: Outcomes and Consequences of Disclosure
div.p: A logical first step to understanding why people choose to disclose information is to investigate the anticipated outcomes of such disclosure. As previously stated, the present research is focused on the psychological rather than the practical consequences of disclosure. An extensive body of research from past decades, either conducted or inspired in large part by James Pennebaker, demonstrates the physical and psychological benefits that result from sharing, including improved health, long-term well-being, and positive academic and professional outcomes (Pennebaker, 1997;see Frattaroli, 2006 for a review and meta-analysis). For instance, disclosure has been found to reduce intrusive thoughts (Lepore, Ragan, & Jones, 2000) and free up cognitive resources (Klein & Boals, 2001). It is also associated with improved immune functioning (Booth, Petrie, & Pennebaker, 1997) and reduced physical symptoms associated with traumatic events (Greenberg & Stone, 1992). The sharing process is said to reactivate the affective responses associated with an emotional experience. Thus, in the case of traumatic experiences, the result is diminished immediate well-being but long-term benefit. For positive events, expressive displays such as celebrating or communicating to others are associated with positive affect above and beyond the benefits arising from the event itself (Langston, 1994;Lambert et al., 2013).

Additionally, there is substantial evidence of social benefits from the sharing of thoughts and experiences, such as building trust and prosocial orientation towards the listener (Reis et al., 2010). In social penetration research, Altman and Taylor (1973) view the act of sharing one's thoughts and feelings with another person as a type of intimacy critical to allowing relationships to progress. As with the outcomes discussed above, intimate sharing of any kind -that is, regardless of valence -can improve social relationships (Collins and Miller, 1994) and attitudes toward out-group members (Miller, 2002;Berg & Wright-Buckley, 1988). In Ensari and Miller (2002), for example, secular Muslim participants rated out-group applicants (i.e., Islamic fundamentalists) more favorably after interacting with an out-group confederate who revealed personal rather than impersonal information. It is worth noting, however, the hazards of sharing, including the potential for negative psychological, reputational, and professional consequences (Kelly and McKillip, 1996). This qualification is echoed by researchers who stress that it is not self-disclosure, per se, but rather disclosure flexibility -i.e., the ability to modulate disclosure in response to situational and interpersonal demands -that is critical to positive mental health and social outcomes (Chelune, 1977).

Disclosure can thus be understood as an integral part of emotional processing, and the desire to share can be expected to persist as long as a memory elicits emotional feelings (Zech, Rimé, & Nils, 2004) or in the presence of another person with whom one hopes to build a rapport. However, recent empirical evidence suggests that individuals engage in costly sharing even when the information is not emotional and absent other plausible motives. Tamir and Mitchell (2012) find that individuals are willing to forgo money to introspect about themselves, and even more money to disclose the product of their introspection to others. Neural imaging techniques employed in this study, as well as in Baek, Scholz, O'Donnell, and Falk (2017), reveal that sharing activates the reward centers of the brain. Taken together, this suggests that sharing thoughts and information with others is inherently valuable and confers a psychological benefit on those who share, irrespective of the type of information or whether it achieves an instrumental purpose.

div.head: Motives for Disclosing
div.p: To the extent that individuals accurately anticipate the outcomes of disclosure discussed above, they may be motivated to share information and experiences in order to achieve the aforementioned outcomes. Powell, Camilleri, Dobele, and Stavros (2017) (Quattrone & Jones, 1978). Similarly, Berg and Archer (1982) found that study participants revealed different types of information when presented with different goals: for instance, instructions that highlighted the goal of accurate information exchange prompted participants to reveal more intimate information than when explicitly instructed to try to create a favorable impression.

More recently, Alexandrov, Lilly, and Babakus (2013) model WOM as driven by both social-and self-motives. In their model, the discloser is driven initially to fulfil what the authors term self-needs (i.e., self-enhancement and self-affirmation), which leads to a social interaction that activates the motive to fulfill social-needs (i.e., social comparison and social bonding) as well as social-intentions (i.e., helping others and providing social information). The model demonstrates how different motives can drive the dissemination of WOM of different valence;

for example, self-enhancement drives the desire to share positive WOM while self-affirmation drives people to share negative WOM. Study 2 in the present paper similarly explores the influence of different motives -including self-enhancement -on disclosure of positive and negative information. Unlike Alexandrov, Lilly, and Babakus (2013), however, we include more diverse domains (i.e., not exclusively WOM) and explore the role of different motives in determining the desire as well as the decision to share.

div.head: Modality and Context
div.p: Different motives can be activated by features in the environment (Omarzu, 2000), and one such feature is the channel through which communication occurs. For instance, the goal and content of Internet communication can differ dramatically from that of face-to-face interactions, due largely to differences in anonymity and audience features (Berger, 2013;Chen & Berger, 2013). Consideration of audience characteristics is important for understanding why people share information, because different motives can be activated depending on the identity, size, and salience of the audience, as well as the relationship between the discloser and the disclosee(s) (Berger, 2014). For example, while self-presentation concerns typically dominate in communication with multiple people (i.e., broadcasting), sharing with just one person (i.e., "narrowcasting") shifts focus from the self to the other and encourages individuals to share information that may instead be useful to the recipient (Barasch & Berger, 2014). Berger and Iyengar (2013) analyze communication from a series of lab studies and a corpus of large-scale survey responses gathered by a marketing research firm, allowing for a comparison between oral (synchronous) and written (asynchronous) communications regarding consumer products. They find that written communications tend to mention more interesting products and brands, arguing that in written communications disclosers are motivated by self-enhancement concerns to avail themselves of the extra time and refine their message to be more interesting to the intended audience.

Closely related to the communication channel is one's communication partner, that is, the availability and characteristics of a potential confidante. One's relationship with, and status relative to, one's conversational partner can influence what is shared and the underlying motivations for the disclosure (Butler, Egloff, Wilhelm, Smith, Erickson, & Gross, 2003). In their meta-analysis, James and Drakich (1993) highlight the importance of status in interpersonal disclosures, and report that beliefs about one's status relative to others can interact with the requirements of the situation, resulting in a tendency for disclosure to conform to performance expectations. A substantial body of literature has explored the impact of the potential target of information on the propensity to disclose and the content shared contingent upon disclosing. A common focus of such investigations is on the gender of both parties to the interaction. For instance, disclosure is often higher to female targets, but men may disclose more to strangers and acquaintances, and women to intimates (Stokes, Childs, & Fuehrer, 1981). Similarly, Derlega, Winstead, Wong, and Hunter (1985) find that males disclose more intimate information in new contact with a female counterpart as compared to participants of either gender in other possible dyads (i.e. female-female, male-male). These nuances can be revealing as to the underlying motives for the disclosure.

In the present paper, our studies include questions that capture the intended or ultimate target of disclosures. It should be noted, however, that we are agnostic about with regard to whom it is that an individual wishes to disclose. Our interest is instead to establish the existence of the desire to share as an important construct, independent from the ultimate decision to share and irrespective of the target of the disclosure. Actual disclosure will depend not only on the desire to share but also, as we discuss in the following subsection, an individual's motives for withholding.

div.head: Motives for Withholding
div.p: Contextual factors can also influence information sharing by changing the perceived costs and benefits of sharing. For instance, online communication (e.g., surveys, blogging) encourages more honest and extensive self-disclosure than paper-and-pencil or face-to-face interactions (Tourangeau, 2004;Harper & Harper, 2006), in large part through the greater anonymity afforded by the Internet which reduces the perceived or actual vulnerability to scrutiny and criticism (Joinson, 2001). Indeed, online platforms that are not anonymous are perceived as posing greater social risk to the discloser than similar in-person communication and are thus negatively correlated with the likelihood to disclose (Eisingerich, Chun, Liu, Jia, & Bell, 2014). Subtle features of the environment that generate disfluency, such as a difficult-to-read font (Alter & Oppenheimer, 2009), can heighten thoughts and emotions associated with risk and concern, leading to discomfort and thereby diminishing self-disclosure. A similar feature that can be influenced by contextual factors, and in turn affects the cost-benefit assessment that may precede the decision to share information, is trust. Andrade, Kaltcheva, and Weitz (2002) demonstrate that trust is a strong predictor of sharing in the context of self-disclosure to companies, which is found to be sensitive to the reputation of the company as well as the completeness of the privacy policy. Similarly, Acquisti, John, and Loewenstein (2012) and John, Acquisti, and Loewenstein (2010) find that activating privacy concerns that are otherwise latent can diminish willingness to share information about oneself. Thus, privacy concerns can act as a powerful motivation for withholding information.

While privacy concerns may be relatively stable reflections of an individual's perceptions and values , and while privacy-related attitudes and behaviors can be captured reliably (Buchanan, Paine, Joinson, & Reips, 2006), privacy concerns are variable across contexts. For instance, Loewenstein (2012, 2013) find that privacy valuations are susceptible to framing and order effects. Thus, privacy preferences exhibit both trait-and state-like characteristics, and the decision to share information on any occasion is determined by a combination of stable privacy concerns and the momentary salience of privacy as an issue, an assessment that is mediated by trust (Paine, Joinson, Buchanan, & Reips, 2006).

Privacy concerns and trust are particularly relevant for self-disclosure on social media and online platforms. Based on the results from focus groups, Krasnova, Spiekermann, Koroleva, and Hildebrand (2010) present a structural equation model of the decision to disclose, wherein privacy risks represent a barrier to information disclosure on online social media platforms that is mediated by their trust in the network provider and the availability of control options. Other privacy scholars have leveraged online platforms to investigate how privacy concerns influence actual self-disclosure. For example, Lowry, Cao, and Everard (2011) conduct a cross-cultural comparison of instant messaging usage in China and the United States and find that culture is a significant predictor of information privacy concerns and desire for online awareness, and that these factors in turn predict attitude toward, intention to use, and actual use of instant messaging.

A closely related literature is that of topic avoidance, which is seen as one possible mechanism for reconciling privacy concerns and the desire for protection against disclosure needs and the desire for openness and intimacy (Baxter & Wilmot, 1985;Petronio, 1991). Topic avoidance is defined as "a goal-oriented communicative behavior whereby individuals strategically try to keep a conversation away from certain foci" (Dailey & Palomares, 2004, p. 472). Individuals actively (try to) avoid topics that are "taboo" (Baxter & Wilmot, 1985), and what is off-limits or inappropriate to discuss -sometimes referred to as "conversational minefields" -varies across conversational partners and relationship types. For instance, the topics of dating and negative life experiences are actively avoided in conversations between adolescents and their parents but less so among siblings (Guerrero & Afifi, 1995), while undergraduates are more likely to avoid discussing dating and sexual experiences with friends of the opposite sex and to avoid disclosing negative life experiences and relationship problems with male friends, regardless of the gender of the discloser (Afifi & Guerrero, 1998). Topic avoidance can be motivated by privacy concerns and self-preservation, but also concern for the well-being and comfort of the conversational partner, preservation of the relationship, or the desire to conform to social norms. Just as the decision to disclose has been modeled in other literatures in the present review, the desire to withhold information is a complex function of domain, relationship to disclosure target, and motivation and represents a powerful countervailing force in the disclosure calculus.

div.head: Individual Differences
div.p: There are not only differences in the willingness to disclose information across different contexts and cultures, but also across individuals. Below we briefly discuss traits and demographic characteristics that have been demonstrated to influence sharing behavior. We include many of these factors as control or explanatory variables in our studies.

div.head: Traits.
div.p: A large body of research has sought to explain variation in sharing behavior across people with different demographic characteristics or personality traits. Such studies typically take as the dependent variable retrospective measures of sharing, such as the Self-Disclosure Questionnaire (SDQ) (Jourard & Lasakow, 1958) or the Willingness to Communicate (WTC) scale (McCroskey, 1992). Disclosure is positively correlated with the need for social approval (Brundage, Derlega, & Cash, 1977;Cravens, 1975), perceived competence and comfort (MacIntyre, 1994), extraversion (Luminet, Zech, Rimé, & Wagner, 2000), and emotional instability (albeit only for disclosures that take place online rather than in person; Berger & Buechel, 2012). These findings suggest that certain individuals may be predisposed to share, perhaps as a means for achieving the social or psychological goals that they value. Given our interest in the desire to share, beyond actual sharing behavior, we are not only interested in differences in actual sharing but also in people's meta-judgments about whether they themselves are more or less prone to share than would be best for themselves. In the same way that biological drives, emotions, and motivational feeling states such as pain, can all drive people to engage in behaviors that they don't believe are good for them, the desire to share can potentially lead to self-perceived over-sharing, and privacy motives can likewise lead people to under-share, whether across the board or in specific domains. Assessing such self-perceived over-or under-sharing is another goal of the research presented below.

Gender. One of the most widely researched areas in this strand of the literature relates to gender. Although it is widely believed, and some research supports, that women typically disclose more information (Dindia & Allen, 1992) to a wider array of individuals (Rimé, Mesquita, Boca, & Philippot, 1991) than do men, the most comprehensive meta-analysis of research on the topic (Dindia & Allen, 1992) found only a modest, non-homogenous effect of gender on self-disclosure across studies (Cohen's d = 0.18). A significant main effect did emerge, albeit it for the target sex of disclosure (i.e., sex of the recipient of the disclosure), rather than for the sex of the discloser: both males and females disclosed more to female and same-sex targets as compared to opposite-sex or male partners. However, subsequent work suggests that gender is still an important factor in determining the propensity to disclose, including studies that leverage real-world data on disclosure in naturalistic settings (Bond, 2009;Sheldon, 2013), data that was unavailable at the time of Dindia and Allen's writing.

Ethnicity. Finally, a small number of studies, most focused on disclosure of medical conditions in healthcare settings, have explored differences between ethnicities in propentiy to disclose (Armistead et al., 1999;Morrison & Downey, 2000). In a study that employs a wider, more representative set of domains, Consedine, Sabag-Cohen, and Krivoshekova (2007) find that ethnicity alone did not predict levels of disclosure but rather interacted with gender, domain, and interpersonal target. For example, while disclosure was generally higher among U.S.-born European Americans, there were no ethnic differences for the two domains of with the lowest levels of disclosure, namely, sexual experiences and trauma.

div.head: Research Objectives
div.p: The present study complements and extends the existing literature in several ways. Both Studies 1 and 2 explore not only the decision (or propensity) to share but also the desire to share information with others. The failure of earlier research to explore this distinction may explain the failure of some retrospective measures -particularly the SDQ (Jourard & Lasakow, 1958) -to predict actual sharing behavior. For example, in an early investigation of the predictive validity of the SDQ, Lubin and Harrison (1964) observed a correlation of only 0.13 between the SDQ and the degree of actual self-disclosing behavior among participants in small group sessions. One plausible explanation (Cozby, 1973) is that, whereas the SDQ inquires about disclosure to close, self-selected confidantes, behavioral measures typically entail disclosure to an experimenter or relatively unknown others, such as fellow study participants (Ehrlich & Graeven, 1971;Vondracek, 1969) or classmates (Himelstein & Kimbrough, 1963;Hurley & Hurley, 1969). We argue that, although important, the intended recipient of the information is one of many possible factors influencing actual sharing behavior, and that the effect of these factors may be mediated by their impact on the desire to share. Using a measure of this desire in Study 2, in combination with a consideration of individual differences, motives, and interactions between these variables, contributes to a more nuanced perspective on the motives driving disclosure.

Prior studies, as already noted, tend to focus on actual sharing behavior, whereas our main focus is on the desire to share, whether or not it leads to actual sharing. Furthermore, in prior studies participants are typically instructed to bring to mind events that meet specified criteria, or are exposed to stimuli that vary on specified dimensions hypothesized to have a specific relationship to sharing behavior. In Study 1 of the present research, in contrast, we ask open-ended questions about the desire to share, providing insight into those events that evoke the most intense desire to share across the universe of possible domains and emotions. The openended nature of Study 1 allows us to exploit variation in self-relevance, valence, and domain to uncover previously unexplored interactions.

div.head: Study 1: The Desire, Decision, and Motivation to Disclose in Unguided Responses
div.p: Study 1 employs a cross-sectional non-experimental design to explore the types of information that most strongly evoke the desire to disclose, as well as to elicit participants' lay theories of what factors might drive their own desire to share. Given its exploratory nature, the results section incorporates a range of, we believe, revealing quotes from Study 1 participants that shed light on this new area of inquiry.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: Participants were recruited from a panel of university alumni and were encouraged to forward the research invitation to family and friends. The only restriction on participation was age (18 years or older). While this participant pool offers some advantage over the often-utilized university student population -specifically, in its diversity of age and accompanying demographic and experiential differences -an important feature of this sample is that it is comprised of individuals who proactively opted to be notified of research opportunities and who are both able and willing to participate in such research in the absence of monetary compensation. This suggests that our sample may be above-average in both socioeconomic status and the tendency to share information. The former would be expected to influence the types of experiences one has and, by extension, the types of information one is interested in sharing with others. The latter would likely systematically bias the frequency with which one shares, or the subjective intensity of their desire to do so. Thus, the findings discussed in this section should be treated as exploratory and expected to generalize only after replication among a more diverse group of participants. Although the non-representativeness of the sample limits the ability to generalize findings to the population at large, an advantage of the sample is that respondents were highly, and intrinsically, motivated by the desire to advance scientific research, making them especially likely to provide thoughtful and honest answers.

Participants were directed to a survey, hosted by Qualtrics, containing mostly open-ended questions. Once there, they were asked to reflect upon instances in which they experienced an intense desire to share information with others. The entire survey flow is diagramed in the appendix ( Figure A1) and the complete survey with programming logic can be found in the supplementary Research Materials, but here we highlight only the questions of primary interest.
Specifically, participants were asked:
• To describe a time when they were "dying" to tell someone something
• What motives drove this desire
• Whether they ultimately shared, and if so, with whom
• Whether sharing could have been (and, if they shared, ultimately was) damaging

Based on their responses to these questions, participants were then asked to recall a time when they had similarly felt an intense desire to share but had made the opposite decision about whether or not to act on that desire (i.e., compared to the first instance they described). If they were able to recall such an instance, respondents answered similar follow-up questions as above and indicated what about this specific experience made them choose differently. Demographic questions were included at the end of the survey. The survey took an average of 20 minutes to complete, excluding 5 outliers whose values exceeded 1.5 times the interquartile range.

Closed-ended questions were analyzed using STATA/SE 15.1. Open-ended questions were coded by two independent coders using MAXQDA. Coders were provided with a codebook developed by the authors based on a review of the responses; the coders were, however, encouraged to modify the codebook as necessary. Intercoder reliability is reported below when relevant. Disagreements were resolved by the judgment of a third independent coder, the judgment of whom prevailed in the coded values reported herein. Table 1 presents the basic demographic breakdown of the 215 study participants who completed the survey in its entirety. Approximately three-quarters (N = 162) of participants were between the ages of 25 and 64, and the vast majority (82.5%) identified as Caucasian.

div.head: Patterns of Sharing Behavior
div.p: The left panel of Figure 1 summarizes the survey structure and illustrates general patterns in participant flow through the survey. The conditional percentages (and number of participants)

who select an answer at each stage are displayed, with arrow widths proportional to number of participants making the selection (out of the total sample, N = 215). This enables us to observe the dominant response pattern across the entire survey. We see at the top of the figure that the majority of study participants (79%) report having at some point experienced an intense desire to share information with another person. Participants were then asked to detail the first such instance that came to mind. Because no restrictions or guidelines accompanied this probe, salience can result from a wide range of factors, such as recency, intensity of experience, vividness of memory, etc. This allowed us to capture a broad spectrum of topics that vary in terms of memorability and significance but are nevertheless capable of eliciting an intense desire to disclose. Of these "top-of-mind" experiences, slightly more than half were relatively innocuous: 55% of respondents indicate that sharing the information would not have been damaging to them. 2 It is worth noting that responding to this item entailed disclosing the information to the researchers; as such, to the extent that people are relatively averse to sharing potentially damaging information, responses to this prompt may be skewed toward more innocuous experiences. While this possibility is especially true of content that participants ultimately opted not to share even with close others, it is also possible that the anonymity of an online survey -which is emphasized by instructions that asked participants to avoid using the names of involved parties to protect their identity -may assuage concerns that discouraged them from sharing in other circumstances. Indeed, this is the mechanism underlying the popularity of anonymous confession websites and anonymous online forums.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Participant Flow Through Survey (by Total and Gender) ** p < 0.01, *p < 0.05, based on a two-sample t-test.
Note: As shown in Table 1, gender information is unavailable for 22 participants. Arrow width roughly proportional to number of participants out of total sample, N = 215.

A large majority (79%) of all respondents acted on their desire to disclose this top-ofmind experience, including 65% (N = 48) of those individuals who believed it might be damaging to do so. However, in only 9% of all cases was sharing the information ultimately damaging to the discloser. Only one-quarter of those participants who acted on their desire to disclose ultimately told the information to a single person: the median number of confidantes was three, and 20% of participants shared the information with more than ten people (not shown in figure). The right panel of Figure 1 explores how gender relates to the disclosive behavior captured at each stage of the survey. A statistically significantly larger portion of males could not recall a situation in which they were "dying" to share information with someone else (25% vs. 9%), t(191) = -2.85, p = 0.002. 3 Conditional on having had this experience, men and women in our sample were equally likely to act on their desire to share, despite the fact that a larger portion of women anticipated damage as a result (51% vs. 39%), t(158) = -1.91, p = 0.029.

There are two final values worth noting in this figure. The first pertains to those participants who appear particularly willing to share information. Forty-two participants (20% of the total sample) indicate that they shared their top-of-mind experience and were subsequently unable to recall any instance in which they were "dying" to share information but ultimately decided to keep it to themselves. A smaller portion exhibited the opposite pattern: 15 participants (7% of the total sample) recounted a situation in which they did not share their top-of-the-mind experiences and were unable to recall a time in which they succumbed to their intense desire to share information.

Those who could recall instances in which they opted not to share were subsequently asked to indicate who they would have been most likely to share the information with and why they ultimately decided not to tell anyone. A review of these open-ended responses suggests that several participants were revealing the information for the first time in the context of this study: Because the majority of participants do not explicitly reveal their interpretation of this question, later discussion of the type of information that is not ultimately shared should be understood more liberally; that is, the decision not to disclose information in some cases may involve withholding the information from specific, but not all, others.

div.head: Domain
div.p: An important aim of this study was to determine the type of information that evokes an intense desire to share. Unlike previous research, our study design allows participants to search freely in memory for events or experiences that they were "dying" to share with others. As discussed above, all participants were given two occasions to describe an instance when they felt this desire, one in which they did ultimately disclose the information and one in which they did not

. 4 The open-ended descriptions of these events were coded for domain in the manner as described in the Methodology section above. Specifically, a codebook was developed by the researchers upon examination of the responses, with broad topic categories (e.g., work-related information) subdivided into more specific codes (e.g., job change, news about company/coworker, etc.). This codebook was then provided to two independent coders who were instructed to assign as many codes to each response as they deemed appropriate to capture the topics discussed therein. Approximately 85% of responses fell into a single topic category, and only three responses were identified as falling into two or three categories. For example, the response of one person recalling a friend's sexual assault while studying abroad was coded both as a "traumatic experience" and as relating to "travel." Coders were given the flexibility to modify the codebook as they saw fit, but only three changes (by one coder) were observed upon completion of the task. 5 Intercoder reliability, calculated using Krippendorff's (2011) alpha, is 0.70, which falls within the range acceptable for drawing the tentative conclusions that follow, and to inform the selection of categories to be tested more rigorously in Study 2. Figure 2 aggregates all descriptions into a high-level view of the type of information that participants were dying to share. 6 These frequencies are then broken out by the proportion of events in each category that were ultimately shared. The types of events that elicited a strong desire to share ranged from important life events, such as pregnancy and medical diagnoses, to more trivial information, as described by one participant:

"Just little things. Like just walking home tonight, and the streets were so quiet and dark, and the park was so beautiful. I wanted to share the experience. I didn't want it to just be mine." is particularly high (93% shared), as is the ultimate communication of entertainment or cultural news, such as "a shocking news story" or "amazing TV show" (88% shared).

A possible concern here is that the proportion of events shared might be a function of the participant sample, driven by an interaction between differences in experiences for people at different ages or of different genders with different sharing norms. For instance, if younger populations are more likely to share any experience than their older counterparts, then experiences more common among younger participants will artificially appear more sharable.

Appendix Tables A1 and A2 put some of these concerns to rest by examining the frequency of different experiences by age group and gender, respectively. We find no significant differences between age groups, and only one highly significant gender difference, namely, the desire to tell others about travel plans is cited more frequently among men than women, t(282) = 2.70, p < 0.01. There is also a marginal gender difference in the opposite direction for information about a social tension or a negative social encounter, t(282) = 2.10, p = 0.04. Otherwise, the percentages are indistinguishable across age and gender categories.

div.head: Emotion and Valence
div.p: As suggested by the earlier literature review, as well as the dramatic contrast between the propensity to share traumatic events compared to good news observed in the previous section, valence and emotionality play an important role in the desire and decision to share information.
Indeed, many participants cite the intense emotion elicited by an event as the root cause of their intense desire to share. According to some respondents, this emotion need not always be positive:

This information was usually emotionally charged, often contained something that had hurt my feelings or felt diminishing to me in some way. Sometimes I am eager to share some 'juicy gossip' but it does not carry the same urgency as a hurt. Upon reflection it strikes me that I needed someone to 'witness' the hurt. (Female respondent, 65+ years of
age)

The open-ended nature of the present study provides an opportunity to explore this role under fewer constraints than in previous research. We first conducted a text analysis to estimate the dominant valence and emotions. The analysis discussed in this section employs the NRC Emotion Lexicon 7 , which contains 14,182 words associated with eight emotions (anger, fear, anticipation, trust, surprise, sadness, joy, and disgust) and two sentiments (negative and positive).

As is common practice, our text analysis began with the removal of all "stopwords" (e.g., "a," "for," "but," etc. we restrict the present discussion to the NRC results, but a similar pattern holds for results from the LIWC analysis, which are presented in Figures A2 and A3 in the Appendix. 8

Although we do not have a baseline measure for the language used to describe nonevocative events, a meaningful comparison can be made between the content of events that were ultimately shared and those that were withheld. Figure 3 displays the proportion of words associated with different sentiments across responses. These values are calculated by mapping each response onto the NRC lexicon to determine the number of words that fall into each valence and emotion category, then dividing that value by the total number of words in the response.

These values are then averaged across responses for both shared and withheld experiences. We see that 7% of shared experiences are positively-valenced, whereas positive words make up only around 6% of withheld responses. This is driven largely by the high prevalence of words related to anticipation and surprise, which are significantly higher in the descriptions of shared (as compared to withheld) responses, t(107) = 1.75, p = 0.04 and t(107) = 2.20, p = 0.02, respectively. The reverse relationship holds for negatively-valenced responses, and this difference is statistically significant, t(107) = 2.16, p = 0.02, driven by the differences in use of words related to sadness, t(107) = 2.46, p = 0.01, anger, t(107) = 1.82, p = 0.04, and disgust, t(107) = 2.94, p < 0.01. 9

These results suggest that the propensity to share is more strongly associated with experiences that are positive, rather than negative. This conclusion should be qualified, however, by the fact that such retrospective reports may be vulnerable to the fading affect bias, wherein negative emotions tend to be forgotten more quickly than positive emotions. For instance, Walker, Vogl, and Thompson, (1997) observe recall for emotional events at 3-month, 1-year, and 4.5-year intervals, and find slightly better recall for pleasant than unpleasant events. Because these responses are the result of unprompted recall, this memory bias might skew the results toward positive emotional events. Our survey design also permits us to analyze responses within subjects. Recall that subjects who reportedly opted to share (withhold) their initial experience were subsequently asked to recall a different event which they opted to withhold from (share with) others. Thus, we analyzed the average lexographic composition of open-ended responses that were shared relative to those that were withheld by the same individual. We then generated a ratio of the proportion of words for each emotion and sentiment for experiences that were ultimately shared relative to those that were not. Finally, we averaged these ratios across all responses. This comparison is displayed in Figure 4. A value of 1 signifies that there is no difference in the emotionality of The above analysis represents an objective but somewhat blunt tool for assessing the valence and emotionality of events that reportedly evoke an intense desire to share. To complement these results, open-ended descriptions were also reviewed and coded for overall valence by two independent coders tasked with recording each response as either "Positive," "Negative," or "Unclear/Mixed Emotion." 10 We present these results after introducing an additional dimension of disclosure investigated in Study 1: self-relevance.

div.head: Self-Relevance
div.p: In addition to valence, another important characteristic of the information people are eager to disclose is self-relevance. Some participants explicitly referenced either an aversion to, or a preference for, conveying information about others, rather than themselves.

"I don't generally spread rumors or gossip about people. I don't really like it when others talk about people or pass judgement about other people. Most of the info I share is about me. To gather statistics about this dimension, each response was coded for self-relevance in addition to valence: Two independent coders determined whether the primary person involved in the event was the participant ("Self") or someone else ("Other"). If it was someone else, his or her relationship to the participant was noted, and in half of such cases the information involved either a family member or friend (29% and 21%, respectively). The reliability scores between the two coders (Krippendorff, 2011) for valence and self-relevance were 0.75 and 0.78, respectively.
Disagreements were increasing in brevity of response, such as when one respondent "came out as gay to a friend" or when another stated that "the information was about an extramarital affair."

These were assumed by one coder to be, respectively, a positive experience and referring to the participant's own affair, despite the absence of specific information identifying either as such. whereas less than half (46%, or 22 out of 48 instances) of the information ultimately disclosed about others is similarly-valenced. In other words, the intense desire to share is most frequently evoked by positive information about oneself or negative information about others, and, while it is more common for individuals to act on this desire when the information involves oneself, the majority of negative information disclosed will be about others rather than oneself. These results are consistent with De Angelis et al. (2012), who find that, when prompted to discuss a product or service experience without restriction, 64% of participants talked about an experience that they directly experienced whereas 35% talked about an experience they heard about from someone else. In that study, the information shared about others' experiences was significantly more negatively-valenced, while the information shared about one's own experiences was predominantly positive. 11

div.head: Figure 5
div.p: Experience and Sharing Frequencies by Valence and Self-Relevance This difference may well be driven by an often-cited discomfort with the possibility of being judged by others, as described by some Study 1 respondents: I tend to keep the very personal information to myself because I don't want to feel judged by others. Even when I got engaged, we shared the information with our parents, close friends but did not 'shout it from the rooftop' -we just let the communication happen [When] I felt a strong urge to tell someone something and I chose not to it was usually because I was concerned that the other person would not understand and that I would be judged. Maybe I was also judging myself and worried that others would judge me, also.
(Female respondent, 65+ years of age)

div.head: Motivations for Disclosing
div.p: The second subsection of the literature review highlighted the interdependence between the type of information shared and the goals people hope to accomplish by sharing it. The present study investigated the motives that underlie disclosure in two ways. The first was in an open-ended question that asked respondents what they thought made them want to share a specific piece of information. The second involved the multiple selection of all motives that might have been driving their desire to share the top-of-mind instance they described.

Approximately two-thirds of the open-ended responses can be broadly categorized according to whether the individual's primary motivation was self-interest or concern for the potential (or ultimate) recipient of the information, with the former accounting for more responses than any other motivation. Most common among this type was a self-enhancement motive, such as a desire to "show-off" or to be seen as informed or important.

"Information ultimately is power. A person wants to share information as a sign of power, as 'in the know,' or providing updates within a family situation to jockey for patriarchy." Some participants reported sharing information for the purpose of getting the other person's advice or perspective, and some reported gaining perspective simply from the act of relating the information to another person -for example, from talking through it as a means of analyzing or making sense of it, or simply relieving worry and "getting it off one's chest." "Someone does something or tells me something that I didn't expect, and I need to talk it through with people who know me well in order to process it. I tend to process information by talking through it." (Female respondent, 25-44 years of age)

The remaining third of responses are characterized by an explicit concern for those with whom information is to be disclosed. These motives typically involve knowing that the other person will be able to put the information to good use, or will be interested, entertained, or happy to hear the news. Some respondents suggested they were driven by a desire to express concern or support for the recipient. The distinction between "pure" and "impure" altruism (e.g., Andreoni, 1990) -i.e., that ostensibly altruistic behavior may be driven not only by the concern for the recipient's well-being but also by the positive affect one derives from helping others -provides a possible classification of such accounts. There are participants who report experiencing a psychological satisfaction with the impact they have on those with whom they share the information. These motives could be classified as "impure" altruism, with pleasure derived from making others happy by disclosing interesting or helpful information: "I'm excited about telling someone something that will bring them joy, or make them laugh, and I love seeing people's reactions to things like that."
