(Female respondent, 25-44 years to achieve a sense of closeness or intimacy with others, followed by receiving validation.

div.head: Figure 6
div.p: Motives Driving the Desire to Disclose (Multiple-Selection)

Three-quarters of respondents selected more than one option from the list of possible motives, and the mean number of selections was four. Participants thus appear to share our intuition that there are multiple motivations simultaneously driving the desire to disclose, some of which may be at odds with other drives that discourage sharing altogether. One participant captures this tension quite eloquently: Any discussion of self-reports of the motives and drivers that underlie behavior is incomplete without reference to the limitations of such introspection. Nisbett and Wilson (1977) document the dangers of relying on such reports as a means to understand higher-order mental processes, arguing that such cognitive processes are often inaccessible to conscious thought.

They maintain that, when asked to report on why one exhibited a particular response, people may be unaware of the true mediators and may rely instead on implicit causal theories based on how plausible it is that a given stimulus would evoke such a response. The motivations cited by participants in this section can be expected to be accurate only to the extent that the true mediating factors are salient and resemble plausible causes for the desire to share.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: Study 1 represents exploratory work that approaches a well-studied subject area in a novel fashion, with the aim of uncovering previously unobserved behaviors and generating new hypotheses. It has been successful in this regard, but has limitations, some of which we mitigate in Study 2. Specifically, as discussed in the previous subsection, individuals are limited in their ability to introspect about the motivations that underlie their emotions and actions (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977). In Study 2 we employ more general, objective measures of motives and traits in a model of what drives the desire and decision to disclose information. Additionally, prompting participants to think of times when they are "dying" to share information requires them to evaluate whether experiences meet a self-imposed threshold that maps onto a level of intensity of the desire to share, which is unobservable and complicates comparison across respondents. Study 2 instead asks respondents whether they have had different experiences, and, if they respond affirmatively, asks them whether they had a desire to, and ultimately did, share those experiences with another person. This approach eliminates some of the problems caused by factors that affect whether individuals recall specific types of episodes and whether they evaluate them as worth citing as instances in which they were dying to share. 12 This methodology also reduces the possibility that responses are biased towards more salacious topics at the expense of those more pedestrian topics that nonetheless elicit a strong desire to share.

We have also previously noted the possibility that, to the extent that the experience of a specific emotion (e.g., positive emotion, as in the fading affect bias) renders an event more salient in memory, its inclusion among Study 1 responses may be the result of memorability rather than its evocation of an intense desire to share. We address this issue in Study 2 by specifically prompting participants to think of both negative and positive experiences. A final potential concern in Study 1 is the possibility that, even in the context of an anonymous online survey, participants may be uncomfortable revealing certain types of experiences to the researchers, especially those that are sensitive enough to be withheld even from close family and friends. The result would be a skew toward positive experiences and to experiences that were ultimately shared, both of which conform to the results observed in Study 1. It is virtually impossible to overcome this reticence; however, in Study 2, we encourage more honest reporting by prompting participants to provide closed-ended ratings about an experience that they are not required (but have the option) to describe. Thus, particularly sensitive experiences need not be disclosed in detail in the context of Study 2.

div.head: Study 2: Drivers of the Desire and Decision to Disclose Across Specified Valenced Domains
div.p: Study 1 revealed broad patterns in the domain and type of information that individuals are "dying" to share with others. In Study 2, we no longer fix the desire to share at a high level,

but instead ask participants about their desire to disclose in different situations they have experienced. This allows us to quantify the desire and propensity to share various types of information, as well as to identify the personality traits that influence, and the motivations that underlie, the decision to share. This study aims to identify patterns in the individual and contextual factors that drive sharing behavior, allowing for a more complete understanding of who shares what, why, and with whom.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: As in the previous study, Study 2 participants were recruited from a panel of university alumni who were encouraged to forward the survey link to family and friends. Anyone 18 or older who had not participated in Study 1 was welcomed to participate.

A total of 552 participants completed the survey, hosted by Qualtrics. Each participant was asked whether or not they had ever had a series of specific experiences (henceforth, "scenarios"), which were presented in randomized order. When a participant indicated that they had experienced a particular scenario, they were asked a series of follow-up questions about that experience, namely: how much they wanted to tell someone else about the incident, who if anyone they felt able to tell about it, the extent to which disclosing the information could have been damaging to them personally, whether they ultimately shared the information, and if so, with how many others. They were also given the opportunity to describe the details of each experience. To avoid fatigue, participants repeated this process until they had answered questions for five scenarios that they reported having experienced.

The scenarios depicted 18 different domains, informed by the findings from Study 1 and constructed so as to include situations expected to evoke a wide range of emotions. Each participant randomly saw one of two possible versions of any given scenario. For 17 of these scenarios, nothing was altered except the valence. For instance, some respondents were asked to recall their most painful childhood memory, others their fondest. In some cases, participants were asked whether their health had ever taken a turn for the better (e.g., weight loss, overcoming a health scare) and others for the worse (e.g., weight gain, unfavorable diagnosis). In the remaining scenario, we varied whether the participant had felt misunderstood by a close friend (one version) or by a significant other (another version). This scenario is excluded from all analyses reporting the effect of emotional valence.

We identified three scenarios to be universally experienced -hearing a story on the news, spending time with a romantic partner, and recalling a childhood memory -and removed the initial screening question so that all participants who were randomly assigned to see any of these three scenarios would automatically be asked to provide details on the experience (i.e., not first asked whether they had ever had the experience). This was to ensure that we collected at least some information from all participants: at the very least, we could gather information on a participant's sharing behavior for these three scenarios, even in the unlikely event that he or she reported never experiencing any of the other 15 scenarios. After answering questions about the scenarios, participants were presented with a battery of scales relating to possible motives for sharing, personality traits, and whether they feel that they under-or over-share. Finally, they
were asked a series of basic demographic questions. The median survey duration was approximately 22 minutes.

It is important to note that the study design generates missing values for a minimum of 13 sets of follow-up questions for each participant. Because participants essentially opt-out of answering questions about scenarios they did not experience, we cannot assume these values are missing at random (Rubin, 1987). However, the primary analysis utilizes maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), which is robust to missing data (Davey & Savla, 2010;Acock, 2012). In addition, we find similar results when we run Heckman's two-stage estimation method (Heckman, 1979) to correct selection bias, as described in greater detail in the final subsection under Results. All analyses have been carried out using STATA/SE 15.1. Table A3). Men and women are approximately equally represented in the sample (z = 0.23, ns).

div.head: Self-Perceived Sharing
div.p: Although the general questions were positioned at the end of the survey, we begin by exploring how participants perceive their own sharing behavior in general before moving on to how much they share in any given situation, as indicated by their response to the scenarios. 13

Participants were asked to evaluate themselves across several metrics related to sharing. They were asked to indicate the extent to which the first three statements in Table 3 described them as a person using a scale from 0 ("This statement does not describe me at all") to 10 ("This statement describes me perfectly"). They were also asked to indicate where they fall on a scale of under-vs. over-sharing, where 0 signifies that they don't share thoughts and feelings when they probably should and 10 means they share even when it might be better not to (item 4 in Table 3). interesting, however, is the discrepancy between the relatively normal distribution on the undervs. over-sharing metric on the left and the bimodal distribution on the right for how well respondents feel they are described by the statement, "I sometimes catch myself sharing too much information with others." This suggests that, while on the whole the average participant is comfortable with the degree to which he or she discloses information to others, there are circumstances that drive a subset of participants to become more reserved and others to become more forthcoming. This motivates the analyses that follow, which aim to uncover the situational factors that encourage or discourage disclosure.

div.head: Figure 7
div.p: Distribution of Self-Perceived Sharing Ratings

div.head: Potential Confidantes
div.p: A prerequisite for sharing a piece of information is having someone with whom the information can be shared. For each scenario, participants were asked whether they felt that there was someone they could tell about the experience, and the majority of respondents (62%; N = 340) answered this question in the affirmative for all scenarios presented to them. Responses to the question of who would be the likely recipient of this information ( Figure A4 in Appendix) paint a rough picture of the breadth of participants' social networks. Across scenarios, the average person indicates feeling able to disclose their experience to people from five (out of a possible 12) different relationship categories, averaging between two and three different types of confidantes per scenario. The anticipated recipient is most often one's significant other or a close friend, followed by immediate family members (including parents, siblings, and children).

Despite the overwhelming sense of being able to share all scenarios with another person, only 18% of respondents actually did so. A handful of respondents (3%; N = 14) reported never confiding in another person about any of the experiences described in the scenarios presented to them. This is consistent with the findings from Study 1, wherein only 7% (N = 15) of respondents were unable to think of a time when they had an intense desire to share information and ultimately acted on that desire. This variation highlights the fact that having a viable confidante is a necessary but not sufficient condition for ultimate disclosure. The following sections investigate the remaining factors that help to determine decision-making regarding information sharing. 14

div.head: Overview of Information Disclosure Determinants
div.p: In this study, as in the last, we were interested not only in the binary decision of whether to share but also in the subjective experience of the desire to share. To the extent that there is not a perfect correspondence between the two, factors such as valence, domain, the potential for damage, and individual differences might offer further explanation. Here we present an overview of these factors and their interrelationships. In the final subsection, we include these factors in a model of sharing behavior.

Desire to Share. Each scenario was accompanied by a measure of the desire to share on a scale from -5 (intense, overwhelming desire to withhold) to 5 (intense, overwhelming desire to share). The average respondent felt a slight desire to share across all scenarios (M = 1.30), but this varied substantially between scenarios. Average ratings ranged from the strong desire to tell someone about an infuriating customer service experience (M = 3.65) to a relatively strong desire to withhold information about a painful childhood memory (M = -0.79; see also Figure 9).

Perceived Damage. Participants also rated each scenario on the likelihood and magnitude of possible personal damage or negative reputational impact that might result from sharing the information, using a scale from 0 ("Certainly Not at All Damaging") to 10

("Certainly Very Damaging"). One scenario stands out from all others as being the most potentially damaging: feeling ashamed about a decision that was morally questionable (M = 5.73). A review of the optional open-ended descriptions reveal that such experiences range from the relatively minor, such as intentionally distracting competitors in a bowling league, to the more consequential, such as lying under oath or marrying someone under false pretenses.

Perhaps more interesting is that nearly one-quarter of the participants who opted to write something in the optional space did not actually share details of the event and instead expressed their discomfort in sharing this information, even in the context of an anonymous online survey.
This is a testament to the strength of possible reputational damage as a deterrent to sharing.

Valence Across Domains. As described above, participants randomly saw one of two possible versions of each scenario, wherein nothing was altered except whether the context was positive or negative. The preference for sharing positive information, documented in prior research, is manifest across all aggregate measures in the present study as well. Figure 8 presents the mean difference in ratings and disclosure for positively-and negatively-valenced scenarios.

Positive, as compared to negative, scenarios elicit a significantly greater desire to share, t(2678) = 5.54, p < 0.01, and a significantly larger percentage of participants feel able to share, t(2678) = 4.12, p < 0.01, and are significantly more likely to ultimately share, t(2678) = 2.17, p = 0.02, positive scenarios, which are also seen as significantly less potentially damaging than their negative counterparts, t(2678) = 18.98, p < 0.01. In Figure 9, we explore the desire to share across different domains and by valence.

Scenarios are sorted, in descending order, by the extent to which a version of that scenario (either positive or negative) evokes the desire to share. Here we see a pattern somewhat distinct from the results in Study 1, in that the desire to share is strongest for those scenarios that arguably have the least relevance to oneself, involving a customer service representative, a family member, or a story heard on the news. At the other extreme, we find that people are extremely averse to sharing information about their significant others. The same pattern appears in the one scenario (not shown in Figure 9) in which it is not the valence but rather the party involved that is manipulated: Participants were asked about a time when they felt misunderstood because something they said was misinterpreted either by a close friend or their significant other. A significantly higher desire to share rating was observed for the incident when it involved a friend compared to when it involved their significant other (friend: M = 2.11; significant other: M = 0.06; t(113) = 4.42, p < 0.01). This finding is likely driven by the fact that the most common person that participants do share information with is their significant other (see subsection on Potential Confidantes), for whom the information would not be new if it involved them. Support for this account can be found in another scenario that proves only weakly evocative of the desire to disclose, namely, an encounter with an attractive stranger. The average desire to share rating for this scenario is among the lowest (M = 0.92), but this is driven by the extreme reticence of married participants to share this "pleasant (and somewhat flirtatious)" experience with others (M = 0.13) relative to their unmarried counterparts (M = 0.98), t(112) = 1.96, p = 0.03. It is again likely that the natural target for disclosure among married participants (i.e., one's spouse) is not a viable confidante and, thus, the desire to share dissipates. This is captured in one participant's description of the experience in the optional detail field:
"The person I would most likely tell was my husband. I did not feel comfortable telling him." (Female respondent, 70 years of age)

Finally, the bars in Figure 9 represent the difference between mean desire to share for positive and negative versions of each scenario, with average preference for positive information represented in light gray. Positive experiences almost universally evoke a stronger desire to share than negative information, with two notable exceptions: respondents were more eager to share an infuriating than an impressive experience with a customer service agent 15 and have a stronger desire tell others about a hurtful rather than complimentary comment said about them by a close friend. There is a slight skew towards sharing "juicy gossip" of a negative rather than positive valence, but this difference in not significant.

div.head: Figure 9
div.p: Mean Desire to Share and Difference Across Valence by Domain

Novelty. Because respondents in this study were initially asked whether they had or had not experienced a given scenario, we have a somewhat crude measure of how common each experience is, in the form of the proportion of study respondents indicating that they had an experience over the total respondents presented with that particular scenario. This measure only indicates the frequency with which participants report experiencing a broad category of events and cannot account for any variation in rarity therein. However, if we assume a similar distribution of uniqueness among experiences with the various scenarios -or, at the very least, that experiences that are relatively uncommon across participants are not described as being especially mundane, and vice versa -we can use this measure to speak tentatively to the role of novelty in the decision to share with known others.

In line with expectations based on prior research (i.e., Cooney, Gilbert, & Wilson, 2017), we observe an overall positive relationship between the rarity of an experience and measures of the desire and likelihood to share. However, taking valence into account reveals a more nuanced pattern. Figure 10 shows the relationship between how common an experience is among our participants and the portion of participants who ultimately shared the experience (top panel) as well as the average number of people with whom participants shared this scenario (bottom panel), both conditional on having had the experience. 16 Negative versions are depicted in red.

We observe a downward trend only for positive information; in other words, likelihood and frequency of sharing a positive experience is increasing in the rarity of that experience, but the same is not true for negative scenarios. The results are borne out in Table 4, which presents a logistic and quantile regression 17 of the binary decision to share and the median number of times an experience was shared in Models 1 and 2, respectively. The coefficients for Mean Portion Experienced are highly significant and suggest that, for positive scenarios, increases in commonality are associated with decreases in the odds of sharing the experience and telling 11 fewer individuals, conditional upon sharing. The linear combination shows that the effect of changes in rarity on the propensity to share negative experiences is negligible (Logit coef: 2.07, p = 0.12; QREG coef: 0.00, p = 1.00).

div.head: Figure 10
div.p: Novelty and Frequency of Sharing as a Function of Valence Note: For three of the scenarios, we presumed that all participants had had the specified experience and did not include the question on which this novelty metric is based. These scenarios are therefore excluded from Figure 10 and the accompanying analyses. Tables A4 and A5 in Appendix for individual scale items comprising each measure). Gender differences in sharing emerge in the same direction as observed in previous research. Female participants rate themselves significantly higher than their male counterparts in terms of self-perceived sharing, and these general perceptions are corroborated by reported behavior: On average, across scenarios, female respondents express a significantly greater desire to share, and they are significantly more likely to have someone with whom they can share, to ultimately decide to share, and even to share details of the experience in the study context (i.e., to avail themselves of the optional open-ended text box). 19 This patterns holds despite there being no difference between male and female respondents in terms of the perceived potential damage that would result from sharing. The role of specific traits is explored in the next section.

div.head: Model of the Decision to Disclose
div.p: As is evident from the above discussion, there exist a number of factors that can influence the decision to share information. Here we explore the predictive value of each in terms of their relationship to the desire to share and the probability of acting on that desire. We begin this investigation by exploring the correlations between individual traits and motives and the outcome variables of interest: the desire and propensity to share. The correlations in Table 5 capture the strength and direction of the association between an individual's scaled ratings for various traits and motives and their corresponding desire to share ratings across scenarios (left) and their propensity to disclose a given scenario (right). Although modest in magnitude, these values highlight the direction of the relationship between the different measures. Taking as an example the largest correlation observed in the table, we find that increases in one's agreement with statements about rehearsal (e.g., "Experiences feel more special when I share them with someone else.") are associated with moderate increases in that person's desire to share a given positive scenario, whereas the linearity of the relationship is slightly weaker for negative scenarios. The reverse is true for emotion regulation, where the strength of one's need to "vent" is more strongly correlated with the desire to share negative than positive experiences. Those relationships that achieve significance are all in the expected direction. Appendix Table A6 presents an alternative version of this table, where the dependent variables have been averaged at the individual level to control for the possibility that responses for the same individual are correlated across scenarios . The directional relationships in that table are consistent with what we observe in Table 5, and the magnitudes are larger, albeit at the expense of some significance to select traits and motives. The principal argument made throughout the present paper is that the desire to disclose is a unique construct, distinct from, but causally related to, the ultimate decision to disclose. The decision to share or withhold a piece of information may well result from the consideration of many factors in a way similar to the cost-benefit analysis in the privacy calculus theory (Laufer & Wolfe, 1977). The desire to share can factor into this model in several different ways. At one extreme is the possibility that this desire is primal and primary, producing an immediate affective experience that then serves as an input into the calculation of whether or not to disclose. At the other extreme, the psychological desire may itself result from the careful consideration of factors, such as the potential for reputational damage, fully mediating the influence of such factors on the decision to disclose. To test this hypothesis, we use the responses from Study 2 participants to estimate four competing accounts of the decision to share using a series of structural equation models, shown in Figure 11 below. Each model takes the valence (Negative) of the scenario as given and assumes that valence influences the extent to which disclosing the information is perceived as possibly damaging (Damage). This represents one type of "cost" that might come under consideration in this disclosure decision calculus. In all models, scenario valence exerts only an indirect influence on the decision to share; this effect is assumed to be mediated by its role on perceived damage. Where these models differ, however, is in the role that desire to share (DTS) is hypothesized to play.

div.head: Figure 11
div.p: Alternative Models of the Disclosure Decision-Making Process (4) Exogenous Feedback
(2) Fully Exogenous
(3) Partial Mediation

(1) Fully Model (1) depicts a situation in which the psychological desire to disclose is merely an intermediate step between the consideration of costs associated with disclosing and the ultimate decision outcome. Importantly, this model depicts the desire to disclose as being somewhat redundant: much like the ultimate decision to disclose, the desire emerges only after consideration of the pragmatics of the situation. In Model 3, we relax this assumption and allow the potential for damage to exert both an indirect influence on the disclosure decision through its impact on the desire to share, as well as a direct impact on the outcome, independent of the psychological desire. In Model (2), we allow for the alternative possibility that DTS is fully exogenous. While we allow DTS to be correlated with scenario valence (as represented by the curved line), the experience or information to be shared takes place outside of this system of equations and engenders the desire to share, which then influences the ultimate decision to disclose or not, independently of all other factors. The final model extends this exogenous account to include the possibility that DTS may additionally exert an indirect influence on the outcome variable via its influence on the perceived risk of disclosing. In other words, it is reasonable to suspect that experiencing an intense, perhaps visceral, desire to disclose information to others may overwhelm other more pragmatic considerations. We also allow scenario valence to exert an influence on the desire to share directly. Thus, unlike in Model 3where DTS was assumed to be influenced by the assessment of possible costs, Model 4hypothesizes that the desire to share is a function of valence and, in that way, valence influences perceptions of possible damage both directly and indirectly through its impact on the desire to disclose.

div.head: Figure 12
div.p: Path Coefficients from SEM Analysis Note: All coefficients are significant at the 1% confidence level except direct effects between Damage and Shared, which are insignificant, p = 0.18.
(3) Partial (4) Exogenous Feedback

(1) Fully (2) Fully Exogenous Figure 12 presents the results from the structural equation modeling exercise. In the interest of expediency, we do not include significance in this diagram, as virtually all effects are significant at the 1% confidence level. The only exception is the structural coefficient between

Damage and Shared in Models (2) through (4), which is statistically insignificant, p = 0.18. We see that all effects in all models operate in the expected direction. For instance, negativelyvalenced scenarios increase the perceived damage that may result from disclosing, which in turn is associated with a decreasing desire to share (in Models 1, 3, and 4) or decrease in the propensity to disclose directly (Model 2). Similarly, we see that increases in the desire to share have a positive impact on the ultimate decision to do so.

In order to evaluate which of these models best represents the decision-making process that leads to ultimate disclosure, we rely on several goodness of fit measures presented in Table 6. The likelihood ratio chi-square associated with all of these models are relatively small, but 4is the best. The root mean squared error of approximation (RMSEA) uses the same information as the chi-square statistic but corrects for the fact that large sample sizes are penalized. Here Model (4) outperforms Model (2), is on par with Model (3), but is exceeded by Model (1); it is worth noting, however, that any RMSEA value exceeding 0.10 means that the model needs to be improved, so all but Model (2) are acceptable. Taken together, the model which treats the desire to share as exogenous to, but exerting an influence on, the consideration of situational pragmatics is a closer approximation of how these factors influence the ultimate decision to disclose or withhold information. We now complement this perspective on the decision-making process with more standard regression analyses that explore the role of various traits and motives in determining the desire and propensity to share information. Given that participants answer questions about multiple scenarios, we analyze the data using a multilevel modeling approach -specifically, a two-way error-component model -to account for the (imperfectly) hierarchical structure of the data. This approach simultaneously allows for random main effects of scenario and participant. The intensity of individual i's desire to share (DTS) scenario, j, is given by:

where 1 and 2 are random intercepts for individual i and scenario j, respectively, and is a residual error term. 1 is shared across all scenarios for a given individual, i, and 2 is shared by all individuals for a given scenario, j. comprises both the interaction between individual and scenario as well as any other effects specific to individual i for scenario j.

Following Goldstein (1987), the entire dataset is modeled as an artificial level-3 unit, with participant nested at level-2 in the interest of computational efficiency. Level-3 intercepts, therefore, are specified for each scenario, resulting in 17 random coefficients associated with scenario dummy variables, each with variance equal to 2 . Similarly, 1 , the variance term associated with 1 , represents the covariance between responses for the same individual i across different scenarios. Gender, age, motives, and traits are modeled as participant-level variables, as they are collected at only one occasion for each participant and are constant across observations.
The variable Negative, on the other hand, is a scenario-level variable that assumes a value of 1 if the scenario version is negative and 0 otherwise.
The logistic form of this model specification is subsequently applied to the outcome variable Shared -that is, whether an individual ultimately shared their experience with others.
Desire to share is included as a regressor in this model, which assumes the following form:

The interpretation of the fixed and random components of the results is the same in both models. We allow for a common impact on the desire and propensity to share of different regressor levels, presented in the fixed effects portion of Table 7, while allowing for individuals and scenarios to have unique intercepts. The variance of these participant-and scenario-level intercepts are captured in the random effects portion of Table 7, and the relationship between these estimates and their respective standard errors suggest that there is substantial variation both within participants and scenarios. Additionally, each model in Table 7 is accompanied by a likelihood-ratio test, which compares the mixed model to a standard regression with no grouplevel random effects; in other words, it assesses whether all random-effects parameters in the mixed model are simultaneously zero. The high χ 2 statistic (and low p-value) for each model suggests scenario-and participant-level factors must be taken into account. With this specification, we can be more confident that our parameter estimates account for the covariance of responses given by the same individual for different scenarios as well as the covariance of responses for a given scenario across different individuals. An alternative model specification employing an ordinary least squares (OLS) regression with no pooling at the scenario-level and standard errors clustered at the participant-level is presented in the Appendix (Table A7) for comparison, as is a correlation table for the relationship between the mean outcome variables and all traits and motives (Table A6). We now proceed to the results. Note: z-scores for odds ratio values (OR) are calculated as follows: ln(OR)*OR/SE. Table 7 presents the fixed effects, taking desire to share ratings as the dependent variable. In Model 1, ratings for all scenarios are pooled, whereas Models 2 and 3 separately analyze positive and negative scenarios, respectively. In Model 1 we observe the detrimental impact of negative valence on desire to share as the highly negative coefficient on the dummy variable Negative. Here, a negatively-valenced scenario is associated with a decrease in Desire to Share rating of 0.33 (on a 10-point scale), all else equal. As in the SEM models above, Negative and Damage are highly correlated (see Tables A5 and A6) but not perfectly so, and each has an effect on Desire to Share independent of the other, as is demonstrated by the highly significant negative coefficients for both regressors across all three models. This captures the fact that, for instance, sharing positive information can at times be damaging if seen as bragging, and sharing negative information that is self-irrelevant need not entail damaging reputational consequences.

div.head: The top left panel of
div.p: The next three variables in these models explore the extent to which agreement with different motives is correlated with the desire to share. Note that measures of the strength of these motives were collected in a different, later, part of the survey than the scenario responses from which the dependent measure derives. These variables correspond to three motives described in Berger (2014): self-enhancement, rehearsal, and emotion regulation. Each measure was developed by asking participants to indicate their level of agreement with various statements on a 10-point scale and then calculating an individual's average rating across statements related to each construct. Items under self-enhancement deal with the weight one assigns to being held in high regard by others and one's perceptions on his or her tendency to brag. Rehearsal is akin to reliving an event through sharing, and is measured as the belief that an event feels more "real" or more special after it is told to another person. Finally, emotion regulation concerns the emotional relief that is obtained through the process of sharing information. (See Appendix Tables A4 and A5 for the specific items for these composite measures). Although all three achieve significance in Model 1, we see that the Rehearsal and Self Enhancement motives are highly associated with the desire to share positively-valenced information (Model 2). Put another way, those individuals who score higher on these motives report a stronger desire to share a given positive scenario than those who score lower on these motives. We similarly see that Emotion Regulation is a significant driver of the desire to share negative but not positive scenarios, and Rehearsal continues to exert influence for the desire to disclose negative scenarios, albeit it to a weaker and less significant effect (Model 3).

The models also include two measures of personality traits. Trust is measured by how much a participant feels they are aptly characterized as trusting in the good intentions of others, using a 10-point scale. Future bias is measured by responses (on the same 10-point scale) for the following statement, taken from Falk et al. (2016): "In comparison to others, I am a person who is generally willing to give up something today in order to benefit from it in the future." We see in Model 3 that Trust operates exclusively on the desire to share negative information; those who exhibit higher levels of trust experience greater desire to share negative information.

Whereas time preference and age have no predictive value in terms of the desire to share, they are important factors in the decision to act on that desire. The right panel of Table 7 presents the results of a mixed-method logistic regression taking as the dependent variable the binary decision to share a given scenario with others (1) or not (0). The models are again pooled (Models 4 through 6) and broken out by positive and negative valence (Models 7 and 8, respectively), and include the same regressors as Models 1 through 3. In addition, however, we have included the desire to share (DTS) in Models 4 and 6 through 8. The coefficients here are presented as odds ratios, such that any coefficient less than 1 indicates a lower likelihood to share than the comparison group. We see here that the effect of the motives and traits discussed above are mediated almost entirely by the desire to share, as illustrated by the dramatic reduction in the magnitude and significance of their coefficients with the inclusion of DTS in Models 6 through 8. Controlling for the desire to share, we see that Age and time preferences (Future-Biased) now play a significant role in the decision to share information. One's likelihood to share negative information is decreasing in age and with present-bias. This latter relationship is somewhat counterintuitive but may be reconciled by considering that it is measured as agreement with the statement, "In comparison to others, I am a person who is generally willing to give up something today in order to benefit from it in the future." This result makes sense to the extent that sharing negative information has immediate negative consequences but positive long-term benefits.
A very important finding from these regressions relates to the dummy variable Male.

Existing research documents a greater propensity to share by women than by men. While the present research confirms this finding (Models 1, 4, and 5), the remaining models reveal a more nuanced gender difference. In the present sample, males exhibit a lower desire and likelihood to share a given scenario only when it involves negative information, and are equally likely to divulge positive thoughts and experiences.

Note that, because participants were asked about their desire and decision to share for only five out of the possible 18 scenarios, the vast majority of scenarios were unanswered by any given participant. We cannot assume these values are missing at random, because participants essentially opted out of answering questions about scenarios they did not experience. To address this issue of possible selection bias, we employed Heckman's (1979) two-stage correction model. Whether or not the dependent variable, DTS or Shared, is observed for a given participant is determined by the following selection equation:

where Traitsi and Motivesi represent all trait and motive measures captured in the survey for a given individual, i. We also include two self-reported sharing measures, a composite measure of the sharing items and the measure of under-vs. over-sharing discussed in the previous subsection, denoted here as Sharing and Oversharing, respectively. In addition, the selection equation includes the term TotalDisplayedi, a variable that captures the total number of scenarios presented to participant i over the course of the survey. This number is influenced by two factors. First, it increases as one's overall likelihood to have experiences in general decreases: any value above five suggests that there are some scenarios that a participant indicated having not experienced, and the larger the value, the more scenarios a participant explicitly did not experience. The second factor is the order in which scenarios are presented to a participant:

to the extent that a participant happened to see scenarios that were unusual for them early in the survey, the value of this number would increase as an artefact of question order. Randomized scenario order was intended to mitigate this latter factor and, thus, TotalDisplayedi is included in the model of one's likelihood to have answered "Yes" to experiencing a scenario that he or she never actually saw in the survey. This selection equation was executed in using a probit model and the resulting Heckman's lambda, , is included in the models presented Appendix Table A8.
The results described above are robust to the inclusion of this correction.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The decision to share information with another person is the outcome of a complex decision-making process, contingent upon various features of the situation and information content. One key component of this decision that has been neglected in the literature is the psychological experience of the desire to share. This desire is itself dynamic and contextdependent, and the present research represents a first attempt at exploring the factors that bolster or moderate the desire to share, as well as to understand the role this desire plays in actual sharing behavior.

In Study 1, we find that the feeling of "dying" to tell someone something is widely experienced but does not alone perfectly predict one's subsequent decision to share. This is evidenced by the fact that those topics that most frequently evoke an intense desire to sharenamely, work-related events -are among the least likely to be ultimately shared. Similarly, both positively-valenced information and information about oneself are characteristic of the information that people are dying to share, but the interaction between these two factors is critical in determining whether or not one acts on that desire, with individuals less willing to share negative information about themselves as opposed to others.

Study 2 reveals that the desire to share information can vary in intensity, depending on the domain and emotional content of the information and the traits and demographic characteristics of the individual. Here, again, valence plays a critical role. Negative experiences are associated with a weaker desire, and sense that one is able, to disclose to others, as well as a stronger perception of possible damage from disclosure and a lower likelihood of information ultimately being shared. We also find that valence interacts with novelty: conditional on electing to share with others, increasing rarity of a positive (but not negative) experience is accompanied by an increase in the likelihood of sharing and the number of confidantes with whom the information is shared. The desire to share negative information appears to be driven by high levels of trust and the need for emotional regulation (i.e., venting), whereas the desire to share positive information is associated with the rehearsal and self-enhancement motives.
Valence also provides a more nuanced perspective on gender differences in sharing behavior. Consistent with prior research, the present study finds robust gender differences.

Female participants in Study 1 are significantly more likely than males to report a time when they were "dying" to share information with others, and female participants in Study 2 not only rate themselves significantly higher than males on self-perceived sharing measures, but also report a higher average desire, ability, and propensity to share across different scenarios.

However, our model reveals that males are in fact equally likely to want to tell others about positive information and to act on that desire, but exhibit a significantly lower desire and propensity to share negative information.

Aside from the role of valence, our model reveals the importance of this psychological construct of interest -the desire to share -in understanding the decision to share information with others. This desire is highly predictive of the decision to share, and the individual characteristics and motivations presumed to drive the decision to share are almost entirely mediated by this construct. That factors such as age, gender, and time-discounting continue to influence the decision to share even when controlling for this construct suggest an avenue for future research, namely, to explore what factors explain the decision to share information above and beyond what is explained by the psychological drive alone.

Previous research has explored how people share different types of information in different motivational states, and the present study suggests that different motives drive the desire and decision to share information of positive and negative valence. Another path for future research would be to investigate the situational factors that activate one motivational state over another, as well as how individuals behave when multiple conflicting motives are activated.

Finally, Study 1 presented respondents with a slightly different task than typically employed in prior research, which confines participants to think about specific experiences or emotional content. Instead, we ask them to think freely about the thoughts and experiences that most strongly evoke the desire to share. An alternative method for learning about what types of information people want to share is to investigate the information that people actually opt to share outside the experimental context, specifically, on the Internet. Future research might take advantage of the wealth of data available on social media sites such as Twitter and Facebook.
Although it may not generalize to sharing in other contexts, this approach has high internal validity and is increasingly relevant in the Internet age.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: Study 2 addresses several of the design concerns from Study 1, but both studies have limitations. As with any sample of convenience, the participants in this study (i.e., graduates of a private university) are atypical in many ways from the general population and the sample is thus of limited economic and cultural diversity. Additionally, the nature of recruitment allows for self-selection and the possibility that responses are driven in part by unobservable characteristics.

Counterpoised against the non-representativeness of the sample, this unpaid participant pool includes people who are intrinsically motivated to participate in research, and who are likely to give more thoughtful, and potentially honest, responses than those motivated by payment.

Additionally, as with any retrospective self-report, the recall task in both studies likely skews responses toward recent experiences or those that are particularly memorable. Two factors that influence memorability are particularly relevant, as they threaten to confound the present results. The first is emotionality. In Study 2, we addressed the possibility that recall of specific types of emotional (namely, positive) experiences may be more salient in memory by specifically prompting participants to think of negative as well as positive experiences. However, it should be noted that, for all but three scenarios, we ask participants whether or not they have had the experience. Thus, any recall bias that favors positive experiences should diminish the response rate for negative scenarios. The second factor that may influence memorability is the act of sharing itself. This can operate in either of two ways. The Zeigarnik effect describes the phenomenon wherein uncompleted or interrupted tasks are remembered better than their completed or uninterrupted counterparts. This would suggest that information that was not shared would be more salient in memory. That 79% of the top-of-mind responses in Study 1 (i.e., the first instances that participants recalled) were later reported as being shared suggests that this effect might not play a substantial role in recall of sharing behavior. But we are not able to rule out the possibility that the opposite mechanism is at work, that is, that the act of sharing may make the experience more salient, or even retrospectively inflate perceptions of the desire to share at the time. Future research using behavioral data instead of self-reports is needed to address these issues.

div.head: Future Directions
div.p: Results from the studies discussed herein demonstrate that there are differences between the desire to disclose and the ultimate decision to disclose. The next step is to identify the circumstances under which they diverge and explore the reasons for their divergence. The models presented in Table 7 suggest some possible factors that might play a role, such as the self-enhancement motive and traits such as gender and age, but more should be done to explore when one should expect actual disclosing behavior to be misaligned with the underlying desire to disclose. Another area for investigation is the persistence of a desire to disclose despite recognition of the potential for doing so to be damaging to the discloser. Future studies might explore the boundary conditions of this phenomenon, as well as the motives specifically underlying such cases and the psychological outcomes of actual disclosure under such circumstances.

The desire to share is closely related to privacy concerns, a central topic in the Internet age. We suspect that the existence of an innate psychological desire to disclose may help to explain the privacy paradox -that people profess to care deeply about privacy, yet share information with abandon.

Understanding this desire may serve to enrich theory and empirics within the privacy literature and across the field of social psychology. While this study marks a first attempt at distinguishing between the desire and the decision share information, it is one of many attempts at understanding sharing behavior more broadly. In an era when technology and social media outlets offer diverse and increasingly public means for sharing information that are rapidly taken up by large segments of the population, it will likely not be the last. figure.figDesc: recently developed a scale to assess the perceived social benefit of sharing, in terms of social approval, impression management, and improved relationships with others. Perhaps not surprisingly, the scores are highly predictive of likelihood to disclose across several different communication contexts. At a more theoretical level, Derlega and Grzelak (1979) identify 5 basic functions that disclosure can address: self-expression, self-clarification, social validation, relationship development, and social control. Berger (2014) provides a somewhat overlapping list of motives for sharing information that, as in Derlega and Grzelak, also fall into five broad categories: impression-management, emotion regulation, information acquisition, social bonding, and persuasion. The type of information an individual shares at any point in time will arguably depend on what goals or motives are activated in a particular situation. Consistent with this account, when asked to imagine themselves in a series of hypothetical situations, participants revealed different information depending on how integral disclosure was to achieving the goal evoked by the situation

figure.figDesc: explores aggregate results for self-relevance and its relationship to valence. Each bar represents the number of experiences described by participants that fall into each category. In general, the events that people describe as evoking an intense desire to share are more often about oneself (102 vs. 74). But a striking pattern emerges: The right panel confirms the earlier finding that positive experiences are more likely to evoke the intense desire to disclose and to result in disclosure, but this holds only for information about oneself. The opposite pattern emerges for information about others: experiences involving others that evoke an intense desire to share are more often negative than positive. The most dramatic comparison involves the two sets of bars labeled Shared: of the 69 instances in which an individual ultimately shared information about oneself with others, 89% of the time this information was positive in nature,

It is worth noting, of course, that not all WOM is perceived to be without risk. Eisingerich, Chun, Liu, Jia, and Bell (2014) find that individuals are less likely to offer electronic word-of-mouth -particularly on social sites -as compared to face-to-face WOM, an effect mediated by the perceived social risk (e.g., disapproval, embarrassment) associated with the former. 2 Responses to this question, and the related follow-up question about whether the decision to share was ultimately damaging, were coded such that any reference to the possibility of damage was recorded in the affirmative, even if the respondent believed this possibility to be relatively unlikely. Krippendorff's alpha (inter-coder reliability) scores for sharing as potentially and ultimately damaging were 0.90 and 0.92, respectively. 3 This difference may result from variation in the experiential base rate of the desire to share among men and women, or it may instead reflect a gender difference in the threshold of intensity that is categorized as "dying to share." This issue is addressed in Study 2, in which participants were asked instead to assign a numeric value to their desire to share specific information. 4 Note that the order of these questions depended on whether they indicated that they ultimately disclosed the information in the first instance that they reported. 5 These changes consisted of the addition of three codes ("Abortion", "Party/event", and "Social Media"), each of which was applied to only a single response. These three responses were treated as a disagreement between coders and assessed by a third coder who adjudicated between the responses. In all three cases, the original codes were deemed sufficient to incorporate these three specific instances. 6 As discussed above, disagreements between coders were adjudicated by a third coder. The frequencies shown in Figure 2 represent the codes agreed upon by the majority (i.e., two coders). 7 NRC Word-Emotion Association Lexicon, Version 0.92, 10 July 2011. National Research Council Canada (NRC). 8 In comparing the results, note that LIWC contains fewer codes for specific emotions.
